resource descriptions.descriptionText: PubMed is a searchable database of medical literature and lists journal articles that discuss Mycobacterium Malmoense. Click on the link to view a sample search on this topic.

ClinicalTrials.gov lists trials that are related to Mycobacterium Malmoense. Click on the link to go to ClinicalTrials.gov to read descriptions of these studies.

Please note: Studies listed on the ClinicalTrials.gov website are listed for informational purposes only; being listed does not reflect an endorsement by GARD or the NIH. We strongly recommend that you talk with a trusted healthcare provider before choosing to participate in any clinical study.
Medscape Reference provides information on this topic. You may need to register to view the medical textbook, but registration is free.

overviewQuestion.answerText: Mycobacterium malmoense (M. malmoense) is a bacterium naturally found in the environment, such as in wet soil, house dust, water, dairy products, domestic and wild animals, food, and human waste.[6166][6167] M. malmoense infections most often occur in adults with lung disease, and manifests as a lung infection.[6168][6169] Skin and tissue infections with M. malmoense have also been described.[6166] In young children, M. Malmoense may cause an infection of lymphnodes in the neck (i.e., cervical lymphadenitis).[6166][6169]

basicQuestions.questionText: What are the signs and symptoms of mycobacterium malmoense infection?
basicQuestions.answerText: Many cases of M. malmoense infection cause no symptoms, and as a result go unrecognized.[6168] M. malmoense infections in adults often present as lung infections with or without fever. In children, M. malmoense infections can present as a single sided, non-tender, enlarging, neck mass. The mass may be violet in color and often does not respond to conventional antibiotic therapy.[6169] M. malmoense infection can also cause skin lesions or abscesses.[6169]

references.authors: Claesson G et al.,
references.articleTitle: Nerve dysfunction following surgical treatment of cervical non-tuberculous mycobacterial lymphadenitis in children

references.authors: El-Maaytah M, Shah P, Jerjes W, Upile T, Ayliffe P
references.articleTitle: Cervical lymphadenitis due to Mycobacterium malmoense

basicQuestions.answerText: M. Malmoense infection may be acquired by breathing in or ingesting the bacteria, or through trauma, such as an injury or surgical incision.[6167] People who have suppressed immune systems are at an increased risk for developing signs and symptoms from these infections.[6167]

references.authors: Scheinfeld NS
references.articleTitle: Atypical mycobacterial diseases

references.authors: Bhambri S, Bhambri A, Del Rosso JQ
references.articleTitle: Atypical mycobacterial cutaneous infections

references.authors: El-Maaytah M, Shah P, Jerjes W, Upile T, Ayliffe P
references.articleTitle: Cervical lymphadenitis due to Mycobacterium malmoense

basicQuestions.questionText: What is the typical outlook for children with mycobacterium malmoense infection?
basicQuestions.answerText: Overall outlook for children with cervical lymphadenitis is typically good.[6168] Signs and symptoms of M. malmoense infections rage from asymptomatic (no symptoms) to long lasting draining abscesses. Most infections resolve within six months, however cases of prolonged infections (>1 year) have been described.[6168] Some infections resolve much quicker, such as within one week.[6169] Complications are uncommon, but may include scarring and facial nerve injury.[6169]

references.authors: El-Maaytah M, Shah P, Jerjes W, Upile T, Ayliffe P
references.articleTitle: Cervical lymphadenitis due to Mycobacterium malmoense

gardCases.abbreviatedInquiry: My child has this. I am looking for as much information as I can get. How does one get it, does it transfer to others, how long does it take to grow, treatment, etc.?

references.articleTitle: Cervical lymphadenitis due to Mycobacterium malmoense

caseQuestions.questionText: How might cervical lymphadenitis due to a mycobacterium malmoense infection be treated?
caseQuestions.answerText: Currently there is not a well established guideline for treatment of cervical lymphadenitis due to M. malmoense infection. Treatment options may include, early excision, antimicrobial drug therapy, cervical drainage, combination therapy (e.g., antimicrobial drug therapy and surgical excision), or observation alone.[6168]  We strongly recommend that you discus your child's treatment options with his or her healthcare provider.

news.title: NIH-Supported Research Survey to Examine Impact of COVID-19 on Rare Diseases Community
news.description: The NIH-funded Rare Diseases Clinical Research Network (RDCRN) has launched an online research survey to find out how the COVID-19 pandemic is impacting individuals with rare diseases, their families and their caregivers. Your participation can help the rare disease research community shed light on the needs of people with rare diseases during this and other potential health crises, in addition to informing future research efforts. The survey must be completed by December 15, 2020.
